captions.text:
This episode of Film Riot brought to you by
domains.com

Today on Film Riot, we talk about my short
film Losses. Hey I'm in that. I know, you’re
like the lead guy.

Welcome to Film Riot, the show that take the
mystery out of the effects and techniques

of some of your favorite Hollywood films,
I'm your host Ryan Connolly.

It has been an awesome day, an entire 24 hours
of awesomeness for us. We're really excited

by the great response we've gotten from you
guys, so thank you so much. And if you don't

know what I'm talking about, we just released
our short action film called Losses yesterday,

which is what wer’e going to be talking
about today as a matter of fact. So if you

haven't seen it yet, go watch that first,
then come back and watch this. Here's what
it looks like…

Now we’re going to get into a bunch of stuff
that went into making my short film in other

episodes like the fighting, the guns, the
cinematography, sound and so on. But for today's

episode, will be giving you the overview.
So, yeah, love to do it you know.

First of all, let's talk resources. Like most
of you I didn't have much to shoot this, we

did this for 200 bucks and it all went to
food and wardrobe. We used friends and family

for the crew. Now I did have the awesome perk
of the red epic, but that was also free on

loan to me from my good friend Eric Kessler.
So, if you like how the film looked, please

jump over and follow them on twitter and tell
them we love them, so much for the red epic.

Would also do another web series with those
awesome guys, you guys might dig which shows

off their awesome gear and gives you lots
of tips for working with things like jibs,

dollies, and sliders. Go check that out over
here, subscribe and whatnot cause were doing

a bunch of them and you might like them. I
like them, I think they're pretty cool.

The other perk we had was my lighting gear,
I've been building my gear for the last few

years so I do have some cool stuff, but I
really didn't use much of it, I only used

about two 1K’s and the light panel for most
of it, and a lot of like $15 can lights which

you can get from Home Depot and Walmart, which
I talk about all the time. I really love those

things surprisingly enough, and I use them
a lot. Why do I tell you this, I'm hoping

knowing this will get you excited and motivated
to do your own thing and although we had the

red epic, and it looked great, ultimately
we show this on You Tube so really your not

seeing the full potential of the camera. I
probably could've used the 5D, and came pretty

close to the look we got. Not completely,
but pretty freaking close. As I've been pushing

you guys, you don't need lots of money to
good do stuff, you just need creativity and

hard work. And getting the short done was
insane, we had such a short amount of time

to do it and it didn't help that we were also
doing two episodes of Film Riot and Film State

at the same time to top that off, we only
had a three-hour window per day to shoot at

the location for most of the short, and four
days total that we could be there. So, everything

was moving really fast. Or moving even faster,
so now I came out of the other side, and I'm

still alive, I thought that some tips to shooting
fast might be a bit helpful to you so it.

Number one. One of the most important things
I do when shooting this fast is to make lists,

and one of those would be my gear list so
you know what you need for sure and before

you leave and when you leave the location
you're not leaving anything behind. But the

most important for me if my prop a list, I
comb through the script and make note of every

little thing I need to tell the story. In
the case of Losses, it’s everything down

to the bag we need to put over Josh's head
in the beginning, the handcuffs he's wearing

and so on. I had a few occasions when I didn't
make this list in the past and it really bit

me in the anus area. Since then I always make
sure I sit down with my script and plot all
of that out.

Tip number two. The people helping you are
more than likely doing it for free as a big

favor and for a lot of us these people have
no intention of being in the film industry

or even know much about filmmaking at all.
Don't forget that, it is very easy to get

frustrated while you're shooting this fast
and possibly snap at someone in your crew,

which is more than likely someone doing you
a big favor. This is one of the easiest and

fastest ways to turn your crew against you.
Fortunately for me, I've never had this happen,

but I have seen it happen to someone else
so be sure you're getting everyone to respect

they deserve. Find a pleasant way to deal
with issues as they arise, and make sure that

everyone has drinks and snacks when filming
for longer than two hours.

That is a huge, it Josh am I right? Yes. Because
Josh was cranky, and I gave him a Snickers
and he was ready to go. Snickers so good.

There we go, super simple tips but extremely
important. Be right back

Domain.com is owning the competition, just
like Josh owned 10 different dudes in Losses.

Our Film Riot fans are making domain.com the
fastest growing domain registrars in the world.

If you're setting up the website to show off
pictures for your cat, brag about your mad

SFX skills, or do something more business-related,
domain.com is the best place to buy a domain

name for your new idea. Domain.com's easy
checkout process makes it simple to find your

domain name and set up your website, without
the hassle. Domain.com's domain discovery

system quickly shows you available names,
making it easy to select a domain extension

that's right for you. Find a sweet .com, or
get a .co and save that character, that's

just one less letter for you my friends. Already
has a domain elsewhere, that's cool. Transfer

it to domain.com for only $7.61 and get an
extra year free. The guys atdomain.com are

actually big films fans of Film Riot and they
want to hook you up, you our Film Riot viewers.

So use coupon code FilmRiot and get 15% off
your next domain purchase or transfer, it's

only what $6.47 per domain transfer, mathematical.
Remember, when you think domain names, and
think domain.com.

That's it for today, again we will be showing
how we did more stuff from the short, including

talking about guns which is coming on Monday
and fight choreography after that and more

stuff after that like cinematography, audio
and so on. So booyaa. But until then if you

want to help your friendly neighborhood Film
Riot, tweet, Facebook and email Losses to

whoever you can, try to get this bad boy viral
and whatnot, if you want to, if you liked

it, if you didn't like it, then you know brush
it under the rug, email us a middle finger.

Also want to thank Eric Kessler, for sponsoring
the short film in letting us use the red epic.

Please check out their website right here,
they have all kinds of cool filmmaking things

there that you guys will definitely like.
I'll see you crazy kids next time when Josh

stabs of poor fool in the net with a broken
pool stick.

comments.author: GeneralGarvel

comments.text:
If you want to learn film Id suggest saving the cash and getting a decently 
used t2i. You can pick one up for like $300-400. Use the extra money to get 
a decent lens. You only gain the swivel screen with the t4i. Which isn't 
really worth the extra money. It does have "Autofocus" for video, but its 
not usable. Get a t2i and get a 50mm, maybe a used zoom and get shooting. 
Or maybe you could use the extra cash on an editing software.
comments.author: Levi Stutzman

comments.text:
T4i. If you are intending to learn films then learning how to use more 
manual cameras is a great idea. The T4i is better for this as it has more 
manual controls and has a large sensor for good shallow depth of field, it 
also shoots in 24 fps which is the standard film frame rate (most 
camcorders normally film at 30).

comments.text:
Relative to the Epic, basically any hd dslr. I got my Canon t3i for under a 
grand. You'll want to invest in an okay lens if you want to rack focus well 
though. I just bought a Canon 50mm 1.4 usm that I love. Unfortunately, most 
places that review lenses do not review them in consideration to video, so 
you'll wanna look out for build quality as much as for speed and image 
quality. The Canon kit lens is absolute wobbly bollocks.

comments.text:
Actually, they used the Red Epic, which is a 5k $50,000 camera. And I agree 
with you one the whole thing about it not being the camera, but the way you 
use it. Now, if you're going to just be uploading it to youtube, then there 
is really no reason to buy a crazy expensive camera. But if you are 
planning on releasing it in the theater or so, then a more expensive camera 
will give you a lot more things to work with in post and so on.

comments.author: NoSevenProductions

comments.text:
You have to get in contact with the current owners of the song and get a 
contract with them for you to use it. I recommend talking to small time 
bands for music (which will cost a small fee or nothing) and using royalty 
free music or else you'll be paying a huge amount of money to a record 
company to use a song from a big band.
